revisions.rev:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Colbie Caillat | image = Colbie Caillat playing in Paradiso, Amsterdam 03.jpg | caption = Colbie Caillat performing in 2009 | landscape = Yes | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Colbie Marie Caillat |alias = Coco | Born = {{birth date and age|1985|5|28}}
[[Newbury Park, California]], United States Of America | origin = [[Malibu, California]], United States | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[folk music|folk pop]], [[pop rock]], [[blue-eyed soul]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter, guitarist, pianist | years_active = 2007âpresent | instrument = Vocal, guitar, [[ukulele]], piano | label = [[Universal Republic Records]] | associated_acts = | website = [http://www.colbiecaillat.com www.colbiecaillat.com] }} '''Colbie Marie Caillat''' ({{pron-en|ËkoÊlbi kÉËleÉª|Colbie Caillat.ogg}}; born May 28, 1985) is an American pop singer-songwriter and guitarist from [[Malibu, California]]. She debuted in 2007 with ''[[Coco (album)|Coco]]'', which included hit singles "[[Bubbly]]", "Realize", and "The Little Things". In 2008, she recorded a duet with [[Jason Mraz]], "[[Lucky (Jason Mraz song)|Lucky]]", which won a [[Grammy]]. Caillat released her second album, ''[[Breakthrough (Colbie Caillat album)|Breakthrough]]'', in August 2009. ''Breakthrough'' was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album|Best Pop Vocal Album]]. She was also part of the group that won [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] for her background vocals and writing on [[Taylor Swift]]'s ''[[Fearless (Taylor Swift album)|Fearless]]''. She has sold over six million albums worldwide and sold over 10 million singles. In 2009, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine's 94th-best-selling music artist of the 2000â2009 decade.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/features/best-of-the-2000s-the-decade-in-charts-and-1004051233.story#/charts-decade-end/hot-100-artists?year=2009&begin=91&order=position|title=Billboard Charts â Decade-end Artists â Artists Of The Decade |publisher=Billboard.biz |date= |accessdate=2010-08-19}} ==Life and career== ===Childhood and youth=== Caillat was born in [[Malibu, California]], and grew up in [[Newbury Park, California]]. Her father, [[Ken Caillat]], co-produced [[Fleetwood Mac]]'s ''[[Rumours]]'' (1977) and ''[[Tusk (album)|Tusk]]'' (1979) albums. When she was an infant, her parents gave her the nickname "Coco", which she would later name her debut album.{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2007-10-07-colbie-caillat_N.htm|title=22 million clicks later, MySpace launches Colbie Caillat's career|last=Mansfield|first=Brian|date=October 7, 2007|accessdate=January 15, 2011|work=USA Today}} Caillat took piano lessons as a child, but lacked significant inspiration until she turned 11 years old, when she became enthralled with [[Lauryn Hill]]'s performance in ''[[Sister Act 2]]''.{{cite web|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/colbie-caillat-p920925/biography|title=Colbie Caillat: Biography|last=Lymangrover|first=Jason|year=2007|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=July 3, 2009}} She realized that she wanted to be a singer, and began taking vocal lessons, performing onstage for the first time in sixth grade.{{cite web|url=http://hoboken.patch.com/articles/colbie-caillat-on-music-education-songwriting-and-stage-fright|title=Colbie Caillat On Music Education, Songwriting and Stage Fright|last=Reuter|first=Annie|work=Hoboken Patch|date=May 26, 2010|accessdate=January 15, 2011}} Since then she has covered many songs by Lauryn Hill including "Killing Me Softly" and the timeless classic "Tell Him" Caillat soon met producer Mikal Blue, who hired her to sing on [[techno]] songs used at fashion shows. Caillat began playing the acoustic guitar at age 19, and Blue helped her record her first song. She auditioned for ''[[American Idol]]'' but was rejected at the pre-audition stage and was unable to sing for the judges.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1591609/colbie-caillat-from-idol-reject-john-mayer-tour.jhtml|title=Colbie Caillat: From 'American Idol' Reject To John Mayer Tourmate|last=Beavers|first=Danielle|date=July 28, 2008|accessdate=January 15, 2011|publisher=MTV News}} The second time she auditioned for the show, she sang her own original song, "[[Bubbly]]", and was rejected once again. However, Caillat expressed gratitude at the judges' decision, saying "I was shy. I was nervous. I didn't look the greatest. I wasn't ready for it yet. I was glad, when I auditioned, that they said no."{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2010/03/celeb-idol-fan-colbie-caillat/1|title=Celeb 'Idol' fan: Colbie Caillat|last=Mansfield|first=Brian|date=March 11, 2010|accessdate=January 15, 2011|work=USA Today}} The popularity of Caillat's [[MySpace]] profile led her to become the number-one unsigned singer in her genre for four consecutive months.{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/16/AR2007071601702.html |title=RECORDINGS Quick Spins |accessdate=July 24, 2007 |last=Stewart |first=Allison |date=July 17, 2007 |work=The Washington Post }} ===2007â2008: ''Coco''=== [[File:Colbie Caillat @ The Malibu Inn 06.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Caillat performing at The Malibu Inn during the ''Coco Summer Tour'']] Caillat's debut album, ''Coco'' was released in 2007. Her debut single "[[Bubbly]]" peaked at #5 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 and #2 on the Pop 100. Two other singles followed, "[[Realize (song)|Realize]]" (#20, Hot 100) and "[[The Little Things]]" (#94, Pop 100).{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p920925|pure_url=yes}}|title=Colbie Caillat > Charts & Awards > Billboard Singles|publisher=allmusic|accessdate=July 3, 2009}} After touring with [[Goo Goo Dolls|The Goo Goo Dolls]] and [[Lifehouse (band)|Lifehouse]] in 2007, she was the supporting act for [[John Mayer]] on his 2008 Summer Tour. In 2008, Caillat recorded a duet with [[Jason Mraz]], called "[[Lucky (Jason Mraz song)|Lucky]]," on his album, ''[[We Sing, We Dance, We Steal Things]]''.Jasonmraz.com â [http://jasonmraz.shop.musictoday.com/Product.aspx?cp=418_13384&pc=JZ19COMBO We Sing, We Dance, We Steal Things Jason Mraz Official Store Pre-Order ] In August 2008, Caillat released a song and video for the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing Summer Olympics]] called "[[Somethin' Special (Beijing Olympic Mix)|Somethin' Special]]".{{cite web|url=http://viewmorepics.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewPicture&friendID=8777613&albumId=2085183 |title=Colbie Caillat MySpace Profile Pictures |publisher=Viewmorepics.myspace.com |date= |accessdate=April 14, 2011}} Caillat also sings on "You" by [[Schiller (band)|Schiller]] and appears in the music video. She has been involved in the soundtrack of the movie ''[[Imagine That (film)|Imagine That]]''; she and Mikal Blue cover the [[Beatles]] song "[[Here Comes the Sun]]". She is also featured in Colombian singer [[Juanes]]' album ''[[La vida... es un ratico (en vivo)]]'' in the song "[[Hoy Me Voy]]". In October 2008, the song "[[Midnight Bottle]]" was included in the soundtrack of Brazilian soap opera ''TrÃªs IrmÃ£s''. She also played herself on this soap opera. Caillat provided background vocals for and co-wrote [[Taylor Swift]]'s song "[[Breathe (Taylor Swift song)|Breathe]]", on her album, ''[[Fearless (Taylor Swift album)|Fearless]]''. ===2009â2010: ''Breakthrough''=== [[File:Colbie Caillat 2009 American Music Award cropped.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Caillat at the 2009 [[American Music Awards]] show.]] Caillat's second album, ''[[Breakthrough (Colbie Caillat album)|Breakthrough]]'', was released in August 2009. Most of the album was co-written by [[Jason Reeves (songwriter)|Jason Reeves]] and features guitarist [[David Becker]] on two tracks. Becker has worked with the Caillat's father Ken.{{cite web|url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/universal-republic-star-colbie-caillat,798058.shtml |title=New Press Releases and CSR News |publisher=The Earth Times |date= |accessdate=April 14, 2011}} Caillat had writer's block during the recording sessions, so she enlisted her friends [[Kara DioGuardi]] and [[Jason Reeves (songwriter)|Jason Reeves]], and they went to [[Hawaii]] for three weeks, rented a beach house and wrote songs. The first single from ''Breakthrough'', "[[Fallin' for You (Colbie Caillat song)|Fallin' for You]]", was released in June. The second single, "[[I Never Told You]]," was released in February 2010. Caillat released two Christmas songs for the 2009 holiday season: the standard "[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]" and the [[Beach Boys]] song "[[Merry Christmas, Baby]]".Gary Graff (September 2, 2009). [http://www.billboard.com/news/colbie-caillat-excited-thankful-for-no-1-1004008451.story#/news/colbie-caillat-excited-thankful-for-no-1-1004008451.story Colbie Caillat 'Excited, Thankful' For No. 1 'Breakthrough' Album]. ''Billboard''. Accessed October 17, 2010. Caillat was recognized as [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]]'s songwriter of the year. In July 2010, Caillat performed "[[God Bless America]]" during the seventh inning stretch at the [[2010 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]]. In September 2010, Caillat performed the national anthem in the season opener game of the [[National Football League]] in New Orleans and a Monday Night Football game in [[Chicago]]. In December 2010, Caillat performed at the [[Nobel Peace Prize Concert]] in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. ===2011âpresent: ''All of You''=== Caillat's third album, ''[[All of You (album)|All of You]]'', was released on July 12, 2011. The first single, "[[I Do (Colbie Caillat song)|I Do]]" was released in February. The second single, "[[Brighter Than the Sun]]", was released in June.{{cite web|url=http://www.clicker.com/web/artisan-news-service/COLBIE-CAILLAT-SAYS-NEW-ALBUM-IS-JUST-ABOUT-DONE-1179639/ |title=Artisan News Service: Colbie Caillat Says New Album Is Just About Done |publisher=Clicker.com |date=November 10, 2010 |accessdate=April 14, 2011}} Caillat performed an acoustic version the National Anthem before the San Diego Chargers v Minnesota Vikings game at Qualcomm Stadium in San Diego on September 11, 2011, during the day of remembrance for 9/11. Colbie Caillat performed her second single [[Brighter Than the Sun]] on [[Disney Channel]]'s Original Series: [[So Random]]. Caillat appeared in the third episode of the cancelled [[NBC]] television series ''[[The Playboy Club]]'' as 1960s singer [[Lesley Gore]]. In the episode broadcast on October 3, 2011, Caillat sang Gore's 1963 classic hit, [[It's My Party (song)|It's My Party]].[http://washingtonexaminer.com/entertainment/2011/09/its-her-party-colbie-caillat-her-latest-record-portraying-leslie-gore-and-huma The Washington Examiner - Colbie Caillat on NBC's ''The Playboy Club]] Cast for the part in August 2011,[http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/08/16/playboy-club-colbie-caillat/ Colbie Caillat first guest star cast in NBC's ''The Playboy Club''] Caillat taped her portion of the episode in [[Chicago]].[http://www.news-leader.com/article/20110923/LIFE/109230316/-Bubbly-Colbie-Caillat-breezes-into-town NewsLeader.com - Colbie Caillat on NBC's ''The Playboy Club'' as Leslie Gore == Discography == {{Main|Colbie Caillat discography}} * ''[[Coco (album)|Coco]]'' (2007) * ''[[Breakthrough (Colbie Caillat album)|Breakthrough]]'' (2009) * ''[[All of You (album)|All of You]]'' (2011) == Tours == * 2008: ''[[John Mayer 2008 Summer Tour]]'' * 2008: ''[[Coco Summer Tour]]'' * 2008: ''[[Coco World Tour]]'' * 2009/2010: ''[[Breakthrough World Tour]]'' * 2011: ''[[All of You Summer Tour]]'' == Awards and nominations == {{BLP unsourced section|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox Musician Awards | name = Colbie Caillat | image = | caption = | awards = 8 | nominations = 19 }} ===Grammy Awards=== The [[Grammy Award]]s are awarded annually by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]]. Caillat has won two awards from four nominations, including [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] (as featured artist). {{awards table}} |- |rowspan="3"|[[52nd Grammy Awards|2010]]
